entry.title: Designing with data
entry.content:
I've been working with charts and graphs lately. Had to read a lot about visualizing data.

Studies of [Edward Tufte][http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Tufte] is quite valuable to anyone working in presentation of informational graphics. One of the most useful concepts was the data-to-ink ratio.

A large share of ink on a graphic should present data-information, the ink changing as the data change. Data-ink is the non-erasable core of a graphic, the non-redundant ink arranged in response to variation in the numbers represented.

Tufte 1983

Tufte is also the inventor of [sparklines][http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparkline]. I also came across the book [A Practical Guide to Designing with Data][http://www.amazon.com/Practical-Guide-Designing-Data/dp/0956174086] which was quite useful in designing visualizations. It covers the fundamentals of presentation of graphics, common mistakes and various chart types.
